ai-dn23:1.2_0: At one time Venerable Kassapa the Prince was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a Kosalan citadel named Setavyā.
ai-dn23:1.3_0: He stayed in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.
ai-dn23:1.4_0: Now at that time the chieftain Pāyāsi was living in Setavyā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.
ai-dn23:2.1_0: Now at that time Pāyāsi had the following harmful misconception:
ai-dn23:2.2_0: “There’s no afterlife. No beings are reborn spontaneously. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

ai-dn23:2.6_0: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
ai-dn23:2.7_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.’”
ai-dn23:2.8_0: Then, having departed Setavyā, they formed into companies and headed north to the grove.

ai-dn23:32.1_0: Then the chieftain Pāyāsi set up an offering for ascetics and brahmins, for paupers, vagrants, travelers, and beggars.

ai-dn23:32.17_0: Sir, you’re dear and beloved to me. But how can I reconcile one so dear with something so disagreeable?”
ai-dn23:32.18_0: “Well then, dear Uttara, set up an offering with the same kind of food that I eat,
ai-dn23:32.19_0: and the same kind of clothes that I wear.”
